name: Preparation & Post-Op Care
pre_op_assessment:
1. Pre-operative Assessment

  • History (AMPPLE): Allergies, Medications, Past history, Pregnancy/Last meal, Events.
    Functional Status: Measured in METs (Metabolic Equivalents).
    - >4 METs: Can climb 1 flight of stairs (Low risk).
    - <4 METs: Cannot climb stairs (High cardiac risk).
  • ASA Grading:
    - I: Healthy.
    - II: Mild systemic disease (Smoker, Pregnant, Well-controlled HTN).
    - III: Severe systemic disease (COPD, Angina, Prior MI).
    - IV: Threat to life (Sepsis, Renal failure).
    - V: Moribund (Ruptured AAA).
  • Airway (Mallampati): Class I (Soft palate/uvula visible) to Class IV (Hard palate only). Predicts difficult intubation.
medication_bridge:
2. [cite_start]Drug Management

  • Stop:
    - Warfarin: Stop 5 days pre-op[cite: 1710]. Bridge with LMWH if high risk (metal valve). Check INR <1.5. [cite_start]
    - Clopidogrel: Stop 7 days pre-op (unless cardiac stent <12mo)[cite: 1703]. [cite_start]
    - ACEi/ARBs: Omit morning dose (prevents refractory hypotension)[cite: 1733].
    - Oral Hypoglycemics: Omit morning dose. [cite_start]Metformin held if contrast used[cite: 1723]. [cite_start]
    - COCP/HRT: Stop 4 weeks pre-major surgery (VTE risk)[cite: 1731]. [cite_start]
    - Aspirin: Stop ONLY if acute GI bleed; otherwise often continued for vascular risk [cite: 1691, 1707][cite_start].
  • Continue: Beta-blockers (abrupt stop causes rebound HTN [cite: 1736][cite_start]), Statins, Antiepileptics, Thyroxine, Steroids (Need IV Hydrocortisone 'Stress Dose' if on long-term steroids to prevent Addisonian crisis [cite: 1730]).
pre_op_prep:
3. Patient Preparation

  • Fasting (2-4-6 Rule): 2h Clear fluids, 4h Breast milk, 6h Solids. Minimizes aspiration.
  • VTE Prophylaxis:
    - Mechanical: TED stockings, Pneumatic compression.
    - Chemical: LMWH (Enoxaparin) 6-12h pre-op. [cite_start]Caprini Score assesses risk.
  • Antibiotic Prophylaxis:
    - Timing: Best given at induction (<60 mins before incision)[cite: 2338].
    - Duration: Single dose usually sufficient. [cite_start]5 days course is ineffective/harmful[cite: 2343]. [cite_start]
    - Indications: Rheumatic heart history [cite: 2324][cite_start], Implants [cite: 2111][cite_start], Clean-Contaminated surgeries.
  • Infection Control: Admission on day of surgery reduces infection risk (proven)[cite: 2090]. [cite_start]Do NOT shave (use clippers) as shaving increases SSI risk[cite: 2096].
post_op_care:
4. Post-Op Management

  • Immediate (Recovery): ABCDE. Check Airway patency, SpO2 >94%, BP/HR (Hemorrhage?), Urine >0.5ml/kg/hr. [cite_start]Temp (Hypothermia causes coagulopathy and worsens metabolic response [cite: 4015]).
  • Fluid Balance:
    - Maintenance: 25-30ml/kg/day H2O + 1mmol/kg Na/K.
    - Losses: Replace NGT/Drain losses mL-for-mL. [cite_start]
    - Physiology: Daily water loss in healthy adult: Lungs ~400ml [cite: 4167][cite_start], Urine ~1500ml[cite: 4159]. [cite_start]Normal Saline is 0.9% NaCl (154 mmol Na+/L), Isotonic Crystalloid (NOT a colloid or energy source)[cite: 4133].

name: Metabolic Response to Injury
phases:
1. Ebb Phase (0-24h)

'Shock phase'. Goal: Immediate survival. Hypometabolism.

2. Flow Phase (Days-Weeks)

'Catabolic phase'. Goal: Repair.
Features: Hypermetabolism. Catabolism (Muscle breakdown). Insulin Resistance ('Stress Diabetes'). [cite_start]
Nature: An obligatory physiological response[cite: 3964]. [cite_start]Intensity varies with injury severity[cite: 3980]. [cite_start]Can damage distant organs (MODS) if prolonged[cite: 3972].
optimization:
Attenuating the Response


1. [cite_start]Analgesia: Blocks afferent neural stimuli[cite: 4008].
2. [cite_start]Nutritional Support: Prevents catabolism[cite: 3995].
3. [cite_start]Infection Control: Sepsis prolongs the response[cite: 3997].
4. [cite_start]Avoid Hypothermia: Hypothermia worsens catabolism/mortality[cite: 4009].
mediators:
Mediators

Hormones: Cortisol, Glucagon, Adrenaline (Catabolic). Insulin (Anabolic, but resistance occurs).
Cytokines: IL-1, IL-6, TNF-alpha.

name: Shock & Resuscitation
definition:
Definition

Acute circulatory failure leading to inadequate tissue perfusion. Defined by perfusion (Lactate, Urine), NOT just BP.
classification:
Types of Shock

  • Hypovolemic: Loss of volume. Preload ↓, CO ↓, SVR ↑. [cite_start]Causes: Hemorrhage (Pelvic fracture [cite: 656]), Burns.
  • Cardiogenic: Pump failure. Preload ↑, CO ↓, SVR ↑. [cite_start]
    Causes: Myocardial Infarction (>40% LV) [cite: 569][cite_start], Pulmonary Embolism (also Obstructive)[cite: 642].
    Features: Pulmonary Edema, Raised JVP.
  • Obstructive: Physical blockage. Tension Pneumothorax, Tamponade.
  • Distributive: Vasodilation. Preload ↓, CO ↑ (early), SVR ↓↓↓. [cite_start]Causes: Sepsis, Anaphylaxis (Bee sting [cite: 660]).
management:
Management Priorities

1. [cite_start]Hypovolemic:
- Address Hypovolemia First: Restore preload[cite: 684]. [cite_start]Inotropes are contraindicated in an empty heart[cite: 679]. [cite_start]
- Access: Short, Wide-Bore Cannulae (14G)[cite: 693].
- Fluids: Isotonic Crystalloids (Saline/Hartmann's). [cite_start]Avoid Hypotonic (Dextrose)[cite: 706]. [cite_start]
- Monitoring: Urine Output (Target >0.5ml/kg/hr)[cite: 700].
2. Cardiogenic: Inotropes (Dobutamine), Revascularization. Avoid fluid overload.
acid_base:
Respiratory Acidosis

Caused by CO2 retention (Type II Failure). [cite_start]
Causes: Pneumonia [cite: 3724][cite_start], Acute Asthma[cite: 3733], Opiates. [cite_start]
Note: Vomiting causes Metabolic Alkalosis[cite: 3732]; [cite_start]Diarrhea causes Metabolic Acidosis[cite: 3742].

name: Wound Healing & Types
clinical_types:
Wound Types

  • Tidy (Incised): Inflicted by sharp instruments (Knife/Glass). Clean edges. [cite_start]Can be sutured primarily (Primary Intention)[cite: 4141, 4153].
  • Untidy (Lacerated/Crush): Devitalized tissue, irregular edges. Requires debridement and delayed closure.
  • Pressure Ulcers: Ischemia over bony prominences.
factors:
Factors Affecting Healing


Systemic:
- Malnutrition (Protein/Vit C deficiency)[cite: 4061]. [cite_start]
- Steroid Therapy (Inhibits protein synthesis/fibroblasts)[cite: 4049].
- Jaundice, Uremia, Diabetes.
Local: Infection, Ischemia, Foreign Body. [cite_start]
Note: Gender is not a direct factor[cite: 4042].

name: Keloids vs Hypertrophic Scar
definition_features:
Definitions

Keloid: Dense fibrous tissue extending BEYOND original wound boundaries[cite: 4072].
Hypertrophic Scar: Confined WITHIN wound boundaries. Regresses with time.
epidemiology_risk:
Risk Factors

Keloid:
- Pigmented Skin: More common in Black/African/Asian populations[cite: 4067]. [cite_start]
- Genetics: Familial trait[cite: 4080].
- Sites: Sternum, Earlobes, Deltoid. [cite_start]
Hypertrophic: Flexor surfaces, Tension areas[cite: 4075].
pathology_comparison:
Comparison

FeatureKeloidHypertrophic
ExtentInvades normal skinConfined to wound
RegressionDoes NOT regress [cite: 4077]Spontaneous regression
OnsetDelayed (>3 months)Early (<4 weeks)
management:
Management

Keloid: Intralesional Steroids (Triamcinolone), Pressure Garments, Silicone. Surgery alone leads to recurrence.

name: Skin Lesions & Malignancies
bcc:
Basal Cell Carcinoma (BCC)

Most Common skin cancer[cite: 4028]. [cite_start]Arises from basal layer[cite: 4024]. [cite_start]
Features: Head & Neck (Sun exposed)[cite: 4036], Rolled pearly edge, Telangiectasia, Central ulcer ('Rodent Ulcer').
Behavior: Locally invasive. [cite_start]Metastasis is extremely rare[cite: 4032].
Rx: Excision, Radiotherapy (Radiosensitive).
marjolins:
Marjolin's Ulcer

Definition: Squamous Cell Carcinoma (SCC) arising in a chronic wound/scar (e.g., Burn scar, Venous ulcer)[cite: 2120]. [cite_start]
Features: Painful[cite: 2182]. Everted edge.
Behavior: Aggressive. [cite_start]Metastasizes to regional lymph nodes[cite: 2186].
lipoma:
Lipoma

Benign fatty tumor. [cite_start]
Signs: Slipping Sign Positive (slides under finger)[cite: 2306]. [cite_start]Lobulation Positive[cite: 2301]. Soft/Pseudo-fluctuant. [cite_start]Site: Subcutaneous (Mobile in all directions)[cite: 2308].
sebaceous_cyst:
Sebaceous (Epidermal) Cyst

Signs: Central Punctum (characteristic)[cite: 255]. [cite_start]Attached to skin (Slipping test Negative)[cite: 257]. Opaque (No transillumination).
Rx: Excision of capsule.

name: Acute Abdomen Assessment
pain_differentials:
Pain Patterns

  • Sudden Onset: Perforated Viscus (Peptic Ulcer) [cite: 3439][cite_start], Ruptured Ectopic [cite: 3423][cite_start], Dissecting Aneurysm [cite: 3443][cite_start].
  • Epigastric Pain: Pancreatitis (to back) [cite: 1999][cite_start], MI (Inferior) [cite: 1990][cite_start], Dissecting Aneurysm[cite: 2005].
investigations:
Key Investigations

  • Erect CXR: Detects Free Gas under diaphragm (Pneumoperitoneum). [cite_start]Causes: Perforated Peptic Ulcer [cite: 1967][cite_start], Typhoid perforation, Post-Laparotomy (normal for 5-7 days) [cite: 1982][cite_start].
  • Amylase: >3x Normal = Acute Pancreatitis[cite: 2677]. [cite_start]Can be raised in: Ectopic Pregnancy [cite: 2668][cite_start], Bowel Ischemia [cite: 2672][cite_start], Blunt Trauma [cite: 2681][cite_start].
  • FBC/U&E/Urinalysis: Routine baseline[cite: 2011].

name: Gastric Pathology
gastric_ca:
Carcinoma of Stomach

  • Associations: H. pylori (Distal tumors) [cite: 3061][cite_start], Atrophic Gastritis[cite: 3047].
  • Types:
    - Intestinal: Better prognosis. [cite_start]
    - Diffuse (Linitis Plastica): Worse prognosis[cite: 3058].
  • Treatment: Surgery (Gastrectomy) if resectable. [cite_start]Palliative if Stage IV[cite: 3070].
goo:
Gastric Outlet Obstruction (GOO)

Causes: Ca Antrum, Pyloric Stenosis (Scarring). [cite_start]
Features: Projectile non-bilious vomiting, Succussion Splash[cite: 96], Visible peristalsis. [cite_start]
Metabolic: Hypochloremic Metabolic Alkalosis with Paradoxical Aciduria[cite: 103].
duodenal_ulcer:
Duodenal Ulcer Complications

1. Perforation: Anterior ulcers. [cite_start]Free gas.[cite: 3133].
2. [cite_start]Bleeding: Posterior ulcers (Gastroduodenal artery)[cite: 3137].
3. [cite_start]Stenosis: Pyloric stenosis[cite: 3127].
4. [cite_start]Penetration: To pancreas (Back pain)[cite: 3150]. [cite_start]
Note: Malignancy is NOT a complication of DU[cite: 3145].

name: Hepatobiliary Pathology
gallstones:
Gallstones

  • Asymptomatic: >80% silent[cite: 1083].
  • Imaging: USG is Gold Standard. [cite_start]90% are Radiolucent (Not seen on X-ray)[cite: 1092].
  • Acute Cholecystitis: RUQ pain, Fever. Murphy's Sign. [cite_start]Caused by stone (95%) or Acalculous (5% - Trauma/ICU)[cite: 2482]. [cite_start]Jaundice is rare[cite: 2487].
  • Choledocholithiasis (CBD Stones): Associated with Pain + Jaundice. [cite_start]Treat with ERCP (Sphincterotomy) or Surgery[cite: 3844].
amoebic_abscess:
Amoebic Liver Abscess

Cause: Entamoeba histolytica.
Features: RUQ pain, Fever, 'Anchovy Sauce' pus (sterile).
Rx: Metronidazole. [cite_start]Aspiration if large/left lobe[cite: 58].
pancreatitis:
Acute Pancreatitis

Causes: Gallstones (50%), Alcohol (25%).
Diagnosis: Epigastric pain to back + Amylase/Lipase >3x.
Signs: Cullen's/Grey Turner's (Hemorrhagic).
pancreas_ca:
Ca Head of Pancreas

Presentation: Painless Jaundice[cite: 2376]. [cite_start]
Courvoisier's Law: Jaundice + Palpable non-tender Gallbladder = Malignancy[cite: 2420]. [cite_start]
Symptoms: Itchiness, Pale stool, Dark urine, Back pain[cite: 2428].
liver_failure:
Chronic Liver Failure Signs


Neurological: Tremors (Asterixis), Encephalopathy[cite: 3749]. [cite_start]
Cutaneous: Palmar Erythema, Spider Naevi[cite: 3757]. [cite_start]
Endocrine: Gynaecomastia[cite: 3767]. [cite_start]
Portal HTN: Ascites (Transudative), Splenomegaly (Hypersplenism), Varices[cite: 3860].

name: Jaundice Classification
types:
Types

  • Hemolytic (Pre-Hepatic): High Unconjugated Bilirubin. [cite_start]Urine: No bilirubin (Acholuric)[cite: 1867].
  • Obstructive (Post-Hepatic): High Conjugated Bilirubin. [cite_start]High ALP[cite: 1840]. Urine: Dark (Bilirubin+). Stool: Pale.
  • Hepatocellular: Mixed Bilirubin. High ALT/AST.

name: Colorectal Pathology
crc:
Colorectal Carcinoma

Right Sided: Anemia (Occult bleed), Mass in RIF[cite: 434]. Obstruction rare. [cite_start]
Left Sided: Obstruction common (Narrow lumen), Bleeding, Altered bowel habit[cite: 397].
FAP: >100 Polyps. APC gene. 100% Cancer risk. [cite_start]Screening: Flex Sig[cite: 1686].
diverticular:
Diverticular Disease

Pathology: Herniation at vasa recta. Sigmoid colon. [cite_start]Rectum spared[cite: 1186]. [cite_start]
Complications: Massive rectal bleeding[cite: 1177], Diverticulitis, Fistula (Colovesical). NOT premalignant.
uc_complications:
Ulcerative Colitis Complications

Toxic Megacolon [cite: 4191][cite_start], Malignant Change (CRC) [cite: 4192][cite_start], Primary Sclerosing Cholangitis (Cirrhosis)[cite: 4203]. Fistulas are rare (Crohn's feature).

name: Anal Pathology
hemorrhoids:
Hemorrhoids

Definition: Enlarged anal cushions (3, 7, 11 o'clock). [cite_start]
Features: Bright red bleeding[cite: 1461]. [cite_start]Painless (unless thrombosed)[cite: 1457]. [cite_start]
Rx: Injection (5% Phenol) for 1st/2nd degree[cite: 1469].
abscess_fistula:
Abscess & Fistula

Abscess: Cryptoglandular infection (Anal gland)[cite: 4216]. Painful. [cite_start]Associated with Diabetes[cite: 4220]. [cite_start]
Fistula-in-Ano: 40% follow abscess[cite: 4228]. [cite_start]
Goodsall's Rule: Anterior=Straight, Posterior=Curved[cite: 1307]. [cite_start]
Imaging: MRI is Gold Standard[cite: 1319].
intussusception:
Intussusception (Pediatric)

Telescoping bowel. [cite_start]
Triad: Colicky pain, Redcurrant jelly stool, Sausage mass + Sign of Dance[cite: 3289]. [cite_start]
Lead Point: Peyer's Patches (Children)[cite: 3279].

name: Hernias
inguinal:
Inguinal Hernia

Indirect: Through Deep Ring (Lateral). Congenital. Into Scrotum.
Direct: Through Hesselbach's Triangle (Medial). Acquired.
Management: Repair (Mesh/Suture). Strangulation = Emergency.
paraumbilical:
Paraumbilical Hernia

Defect adjacent to umbilicus[cite: 713]. Adults (Obesity/Multiparity). [cite_start]Does NOT resolve spontaneously[cite: 715]. [cite_start]High strangulation risk -> Surgery recommended[cite: 769].

name: Breast Pathology
malignancy:
Breast Carcinoma

Signs: Peau d'orange (Lymphatic edema) [cite: 944][cite_start], Skin puckering (Cooper's lig infiltration)[cite: 931]. [cite_start]
Staging (T2N2M1): T2 (2-5cm), N2 (Fixed nodes)[cite: 3516], M1 (Metastasis).
Prognosis: Size, Nodes, Receptor status (ER/PR/HER2).
benign:
Benign Lesions

Fibroadenoma: 'Mouse' of breast. Benign neoplasm. [cite_start]Adolescents/Young women[cite: 4107]. [cite_start]Diagnose by Triple Assessment[cite: 4109].
Gynaecomastia: Male breast enlargement. [cite_start]Causes: Liver failure, Digoxin, Spironolactone[cite: 1037], Klinefelter's.
nipple_discharge:
Blood Stained Discharge

Seen in: Duct Ectasia [cite: 3943][cite_start], Intraductal Papilloma [cite: 3946][cite_start], Paget's Disease [cite: 3953][cite_start], Carcinoma[cite: 3957]. Fibroadenoma does NOT cause bloody discharge.

name: Thyroid Pathology
neoplasms:
Malignancies

  • Papillary: Most common (80%)[cite: 2828]. Lymphatic spread.
  • Follicular: Haematogenous spread. [cite_start]Linked to Radiation[cite: 2835].
  • Medullary: From C-Cells (Calcitonin). Not differentiated.
neck_lumps:
Movement

Swallows Up: Thyroid Adenoma[cite: 3925], Thyroglossal Cyst, Pretracheal Nodes. [cite_start]
No Movement: Carotid Body Tumor[cite: 3921].

name: Urology Pathology
bladder_ca:
Bladder Cancer

Males > Females. [cite_start]Risk: Smoking, Dye Exposure[cite: 3584].
Type: TCC (>90%). [cite_start]Chronic irritation (Stones/Schisto) -> SCC[cite: 3593]. [cite_start]
Prognosis: Good in superficial tumors[cite: 3603].
bph:
BPH

Transitional Zone. [cite_start]Hormonal imbalance[cite: 3652]. Common cause of retention. [cite_start]NOT premalignant[cite: 3656].
hydronephrosis:
Hydronephrosis

Bilateral Causes: BPH [cite: 1602][cite_start], Ca Cervix [cite: 1617][cite_start], Retroperitoneal Fibrosis[cite: 1607].
Unilateral: Stone, Aberrant vessel.
varicocele:
Varicocele

Dilated pampiniform plexus. 90% Left sided. [cite_start]Associated with Infertility [cite: 3167] [cite_start]and Left Renal Tumor (if sudden onset)[cite: 3166]. Surgery if symptomatic.
catheter:
Catheterization

Clean with Povidone Iodine[cite: 1479]. [cite_start]Inflate balloon with Sterile Water (not saline)[cite: 1487]. [cite_start]Contraindicated in Urethral Injury[cite: 1501].
ureter_landmarks:
Ureter Radiology

Landmarks: Tips of lumbar transverse processes [cite: 3624][cite_start], Sacro-iliac joint[cite: 3617].

name: Sterilization & Infection
methods:
Sterilization

Destroys ALL organisms + Spores[cite: 2262].
Autoclave: Moist heat. [cite_start]Kills spores[cite: 2229]. Used for metal.
Hospital Methods: Filtration, Irradiation, Dry heat.
infection_control:
Reducing SSI

Proven: Admission on day of surgery [cite: 2090][cite_start], Prophylactic Antibiotics [cite: 2107][cite_start], Early Physiotherapy[cite: 2103]. [cite_start]
Bad Practice: Shaving (Increases risk)[cite: 2095]. [cite_start]Indwelling catheters (Infection source)[cite: 2112].

name: Flail Chest
features:
Features

Fracture >2 ribs in >2 places. [cite_start]Paradoxical Movement[cite: 2436]. [cite_start]
Hypoxia: Due to underlying Pulmonary Contusion and Pain (Splinting)[cite: 2440].
management:
Management

Analgesia is priority. [cite_start]Intubation only if severe respiratory failure[cite: 2441]. [cite_start]Surgery not always indicated[cite: 2445].
